questions.question: What is the primary function of ribosomes?
options: Protein synthesis: translating mRNA into polypeptide chains
DNA replication: coordinating the assembly of a new daughter strand from a DNA template
Generating high-yield ATP molecules via the electron transport chain in the mitochondria
Synthesizing phospholipids and steroids to maintain the structural integrity of the cell membrane
questions.explanation: Ribosomes are molecular machines that catalyze protein synthesis by linking amino acids together in the sequence specified by mRNA.

questions.question: What are the two main structural subunits of ribosomes and their size classifications?
options: Large subunit (50S/60S) and small subunit (30S/40S) that combine to form 70S or 80S
A single, massive globular protein complex that remains fully assembled throughout the entire cell cycle
Three equal-sized subunits that assemble in a random sequence depending on the type of protein being built
Identical structural subunits that are exactly the same size in all prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms
questions.explanation: Ribosomes consist of two unequal subunits. S-values indicate sedimentation rates: prokaryotes use 70S (50S+30S), while eukaryotes use 80S (60S+40S).

questions.question: What is the chemical composition of ribosomes?
options: Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and ribosomal proteins in roughly equal proportions
A core of pure structural proteins with a thin external coating of phospholipid molecules
Long-chain messenger RNA (mRNA) wrapped tightly around a cluster of protective histone proteins
A specialized form of enzymatic DNA that allows the organelle to replicate itself within the cytoplasm
questions.explanation: Ribosomes are ribonucleoprotein complexes (approx. 60% rRNA and 40% protein). The rRNA acts as a ribozyme to catalyze bond formation.

questions.question: What are the three main sites on ribosomes for tRNA binding during translation?
options: A site (aminoacyl), P site (peptidyl), and E site (exit)
A single, multi-functional binding site that handles all tRNA molecules simultaneously
The B site (beginning), M site (middle), and F site (finish) used for sequential amino acid loading
Sites 1, 2, and 3 which are designated based on the total electrical charge of the incoming tRNA
questions.explanation: tRNAs move through the A (arrival), P (processing/peptide bond), and E (exit) sites in order during the elongation phase of translation.

questions.question: What is the difference between free and bound ribosomes?
options: Free ribosomes make cytosolic proteins; bound ribosomes make proteins for secretion or membranes
Free ribosomes are the only ones capable of synthesis, while bound ribosomes act as storage units
Bound ribosomes are found only in prokaryotes, while free ribosomes are found only in eukaryotic cells
There is no functional difference; they are both used to create the same types of proteins for the same locations
questions.explanation: While structurally identical, their location dictates the destination of the protein being produced (cytoplasm vs. endomembrane system/secretion).

questions.question: What is the peptidyl transferase activity and where is it located?
options: Catalytic activity that forms peptide bonds; resides in the rRNA of the large subunit
A specialized cytoplasmic enzyme that attaches specific amino acids to their corresponding tRNA molecules
A catabolic activity responsible for breaking down misfolded proteins into their individual amino acids
A structural protein located in the small subunit that helps the ribosome attach to the mRNA strand
questions.explanation: Peptidyl transferase is a ribozyme (an RNA enzyme) located in the large subunit that facilitates the bond between amino acids.

questions.question: How are ribosomes assembled in eukaryotic cells?
options: rRNA is made in the nucleolus, paired with imported proteins, and subunits are exported separately
They are fully assembled in the cytoplasm from various metabolic precursors found in the cytosol
The small and large subunits self-assemble spontaneously on the surface of the mitochondria
They are produced in the Golgi apparatus and transported to the rough ER via specialized vesicles
questions.explanation: Subunits are partially assembled in the nucleolus before being moved through nuclear pores into the cytoplasm.

questions.question: Which antibiotics target ribosomes and how do they function?
options: Tetracycline and erythromycin inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to ribosomal subunits
Penicillin and vancomycin target the ribosomes to prevent the bacteria from replicating their genetic code
Most antibiotics strengthen the host's ribosomes to help them produce protective antibodies faster
Antibiotics only affect the cell wall and have no physical interaction with the ribosome or protein synthesis
questions.explanation: Antibiotics like tetracycline exploit structural differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic ribosomes to stop bacterial growth.

questions.question: What is polyribosome (polysome) formation and why is it advantageous?
options: Multiple ribosomes translating the same mRNA simultaneously to increase production speed
The fusion of several small subunits into a larger complex to handle much longer strands of DNA
A survival mechanism where ribosomes aggregate into clusters to survive high temperatures or low pH
A rare mutation that causes the cell to overproduce ribosomes, leading to a massive decrease in energy efficiency
questions.explanation: Polysomes allow a cell to produce many copies of a polypeptide very quickly from a single mRNA template.

questions.question: What evolutionary evidence do ribosomes provide about the origin of life?
options: rRNA is highly conserved across all life, suggesting it existed in the common ancestor of all cells
The fact that ribosomes evolved independently in plants and animals proves life has multiple origins
The differences in ribosomes between humans and bacteria show they share no evolutionary connection
Ribosomal proteins are far more conserved than rRNA, indicating proteins were the first genetic material
questions.explanation: Because ribosomes are essential to all life and highly conserved, rRNA sequences are used to trace the ancient history of all living things.
